title: Pro Log: Four arrested for planned protest at the Vuelta, Cecilie Uttrup Ludwig lights up Tour of Scandinavia as Annemiek van Vleuten wins overall, Marianne Vos ends season after surgery and Josh Tarling becomes joint youngest WorldTour stage winner
content:
Cyclist
Pro Log: Four arrested for planned protest at the Vuelta, Cecilie Uttrup Ludwig lights up Tour of Scandinavia as Annemiek van Vleuten wins overall, Marianne Vos ends season after surgery and Josh Tarling becomes joint youngest WorldTour stage winner

Welcome back to another edition of Pro Log. Germanyâ€™s Antonia Niedermaier won the opening stage individual time-trial at the first edition of the Tour de lâ€™Avenir Femmes yesterday â€“ a race that marks a historic moment and an important step for under-23 riders in the womenâ€™s peloton. Meanwhile Tim Wellens (UAE Team Emirates) won the Renewi Tour overall and Annemiek van Vleuten reigned victorious in the Tour of Scandinaviaâ€™s general classification.

The Vuelta a EspaÃ±a is also underway, but it hasnâ€™t been plain sailing so farâ€¦

Before the start of Stage 4 of the Vuelta in Andorra la Vella, the National Police Corps in Spain said that they had arrested four people in connection with a plan to pour 400 litres of olive oil from a bridge and on to the peloton during Stage 3..

Thereâ€™s been much to discuss at the Vuelta already despite only being four stages in. A team time-trial in the dark, rider protests and a neutralisation, commissaires having to use fansâ€™ videos to confirm official positioning, tacks thrown onto the road, Remco Evenepoel winning and immediately crashing into the Andorran police press officer, and the Jumbo-Visma and Soudal-QuickStep buses breaking.

Cecilie Uttrup Ludwig lights up Tour of Scandinavia

Annemiek van Vleuten (Movistar) won the Tour of Scandinavia by two seconds ahead of FDJ-Suezâ€™s Cecilie Uttrup Ludwig in a thrilling race over five stages. Making her presence felt on the very first day â€“ which was also her birthday â€“ Uttrup Ludwig launched an attack towards the finish as sprint trains swarmed behind. She was pipped by SD Worxâ€™s Lorena Wiebes just metres from the line. Not deterred on the following dayâ€™s Queen Stage, Uttrup Ludwig again dug deep and let out an almighty scream after winning in Norefjell ahead of Van Vleuten. In her typical post-race scene, she exuded happiness while clutching a can of Fanta. Â 

After teammate Grace Brown topped the standings in the Stage 4 ITT, Uttrup Ludwig went into the final day 17 seconds down on Van Vleuten. As torrential rain came down, Uttrup Ludwig attacked in the final kilometre for the win and the bonus seconds. She made sure it wasnâ€™t a repeat of Stage 1 and although it wasnâ€™t enough for the overall victory she claimed another stage win in her home country, collapsing on the tarmac after the finish, lying starfished on the wet ground, exhausted from her efforts. The phrase â€˜fucking go!â€™ was plastered on her handlebars. I love it.

Marianne Vos ends season

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Marianne Vos (@mariannevosofficial)

After winning a round of the UCI Gravel World Series in Sweden, Marianne Vos announced she will end her season early due to undergoing surgery on her left iliac artery. In an Instagram post, she revealed she had been struggling with pain and lack in power in her left leg for a long period of time, and that symptoms had become worse this season. She had another surgery on her iliac artery in February this year.

Vos said, â€˜My biggest hope for now is to be able to return to competition without symptoms. I would love to continue riding and racing at the highest level and will surely do my utterly best to be back.â€™

Josh Tarling becomes joint youngest winner at WorldTour level

British rider Josh Tarling (Ineos Grenadiers), who recently won bronze in the menâ€™s elite ITT at the UCI Cycling World Championships in Glasgow, has equalled the record for youngest winner at WorldTour level with his Stage 2 ITT victory at the Renewi Tour. He beat Tim Wellens (UAE Team Emirates) by 14 seconds.

By winning at just 19 years and 190 days old, Tarling matches none other than Remco Evenepoel at the 2019 ClÃ¡sica de San SebastiÃ¡n. Some feat.

See you next week.
